description: 19th century, from French chéloïde, from Ancient Greek χηλή (khēlḗ, “hoof”) and -oid.

entries.meaning: (pathology) A hard raised growth of scar tissue at the site of an injury.

verbs.description: keloid (third-person singular simple present keloids, present participle keloiding, simple past and past participle keloided)

examples: The scar on his neck from running through that plate glass on one of our licks has keloided smooth and shiny.
